title: Trump and the Reagan Standard
summary: Maybe this is why the White House is optimistic about re-election.. Ronald Reagan got elected President in 1980 by posing a simple question to American voters: "Are you better off than you were four years ago?" The answers doomed incumbent Jimmy Carter, who struggled to address a sagging economy at home and an expanding communist threat abroad. In 1984, U.S. voters answered Reagan's question again by handing him a 49-state landslide re-election victory.

title: House Backs Bill to Curb Robocalls
summary: Measure gives U.S. tougher enforcement tools; Senate is expected to pass it. title: Marines May Need More, but the Navy Helps
summary: All four military services are struggling to meet the challenges of a world where the U.S.'s interests are simultaneously challenged in Asia, Europe and the Middle East. It shouldn't be described in Army versus Navy terms, it's a national issue.. Regarding Steve Cohen's "Army Beats Navy in the Battle of the Budget" (op-ed, Nov. 27): The Navy is indeed short the number of ships it needs to execute the national defense strategy. As he points out, the Navy only has 291 ships against a requirement of 355. And this shortfall does create hazards and risks for the nation and its sailors.

title: California's No Model for Bigger Government
summary: Despite a "vigorous national economy" and record spending, due to questionable policy, California "is increasingly beset by social and economic problems.". Steven Malanga is right that despite a "vigorous national economy" and record spending, due to questionable policy, California "is increasingly beset by social and economic problems" ("California's Spending Boom Masks a Spate of Problems," Cross Country, Nov. 23). Watching the recent Democratic presidential debate, I was shocked to see the candidates advocating for dramatically increasing the size and scope of government involvement in a number of areas, even though many of them hail from areas notorious for wildly inefficient government-run projects-have we already forgotten Boston's Big Dig?

title: Who Knew Debs Supported Gun Rights for Individuals?
summary: If Bernie Sanders turns against gun ownership, it won't be because "the biggest far-leftist since Eugene Debs" revives the principles of his socialist progenitor.. Regarding Charles Ian Campbell's letter of Nov. 20 responding to your editorial "Socialist Against Confiscation" (Nov. 14): If Bernie Sanders turns against gun ownership, it won't be because "the biggest far-leftist since Eugene Debs" revives the principles of his socialist progenitor. As Debs told the readers of the International Socialist Review (September 1914): "Recollect that in arming yourselves, as you are bound to do unless you are willing to be forced into abject slavery, you are safely within the spirit and letter of the law. The constitution of the United States guarantees to you the right to bear arms, as it does to every other citizen."

title: Damning the Billionaires Doesn't Address Spending
summary: It would be better if we turned our attention to what we need as a society and how to get there without damning a group as having undue privilege, thereby undermining what makes the U.S. great.. Regarding "Capital Account: What Could Happen With Fewer Billionaires" (U.S. News, Nov. 21): This is not a zero-sum game whereby if billionaires lose their wealth, we become wealthier. If one were to choose which entity he would prefer managing the U.S. economy-a group of billionaire businesspeople or the federal government-I think the choice would be a no-brainer.

title: Shrinking Airplane Seats Afflict Babies and Mothers
summary: You used to be able to fit an infant on your lap in an airplane.. The shrinking seat, expanding public and sold-out flights are indeed making air travel a miserable experience ("The Middle Seat: When the Plane Seat Doesn't Fit," Life & Arts, Nov. 21). I was on a recent totally full, five-hour, cross-country flight sitting in front of a mother with an 18-month-old on her lap (who was kicking my seat for the entire flight). To be fair, you used to be able to fit an infant on your lap. Given the issues the article raises, I am not sure how one can transport an infant safely. So, let's add new mothers to the list of those disenfranchised by this troubling trend.

title: The Gem of the French Riviera-For 150 Years
summary: Luminaries in the worlds of fashion, film, music and art have long flocked to the Hotel du Cap-Eden-Roc as a summer retreat. On the eve of the establishment's 150th year, regulars recount its evolution into the 21st century.. Forty-eight hours before the 72nd Festival de Cannes kicks off in mid-May, Arnaud Poëtte, longtime executive chef at the Hotel du Cap-Eden-Roc in Cap d'Antibes, has been trimming baby artichokes for days. Before the film festival ends, he and his team will have cleaned, cooked and vacuum-sealed more than a thousand miniature thistles, in preparation for the yearly amfAR gala that raises millions for AIDS research. For the past 11 years the glittery soirée has been hosted at the hotel toward the end of the festival's two-week run of poolside deal-making and red-carpet premieres.

title: Appeals Court Rules Against Trump on Subpoenas to Banks
summary: President Trump had sought to quash subpoenas issued by House Democrats for financial records. A federal appeals court ruled House Democrats can enforce subpoenas to two banks seeking a broad range of President Trump's financial records, as well as those of his family and their businesses.

title: Watchdog Report Details Problems Between FBI and Justice Department
summary: Report on early steps in Russia investigation could lead to changes in bureau's culture. WASHINGTON-A highly anticipated watchdog report is expected to detail significant problems with how the FBI has shared information with the Justice Department and could prompt changes to those practices and the bureau's culture, according to people familiar with the findings.

title: Where's a Trump Tweet When We Need It?
summary: There's a better way to respond to foolish and unreasonable French taxes.. France has designed a new tax to hit American technology companies. In response, President Trump is threatening to add new U.S. taxes on imported French wine and cheese, among other items. A better approach would be to make fun of the French government and increase U.S. imports of French people.

title: Senate Republicans Warm to Theory of Ukrainian Election Interference
summary: Some GOP senators are embracing the idea, advanced by President Trump, that Ukraine meddled in the 2016 race, despite contradictory findings. Some Republican lawmakers are warming to the allegation that Ukraine's government meddled in the 2016 U.S. elections, even though a bipartisan Senate investigation found no evidence of any systematic effort by Ukraine to interfere.

title: Kamala Harris to Drop Out of Presidential Race
summary: Democrat failed to catch fire with voters and was one of only seven to qualify for December debate. California Sen. Kamala Harris said she is dropping out of the Democratic presidential race, completing a surprising fall for a once-promising contender who drew 20,000 people to her campaign launch early this year.

title: Mr. Schiff's Impeachment Opus
summary: His overstatements reveal the weakness of the Democratic case.. These columns warned that once the machinery of impeachment was up and running, it would be impossible to stop. And so on Tuesday Adam Schiff released his House Intelligence Committee report on Ukraine that finds President Trump guilty of playing domestic politics with foreign policy. But it's clear the President's real sin is being the willful, undisciplined Donald Trump voters elected.

title: Kamala Harris Returns to the Senate
summary: The Californian never offered a compelling reason she should be President.. Three to four percent of the Democratic primary electorate went up for grabs Tuesday as Kamala Harris left the presidential contest. The California Senator's polling collapse is a reminder that an appealing biography is no substitute in presidential politics for a command of the issues and a realistic theory of the race.

title: Pelosi's Never-Ending Trade Demands
summary: The U.S.-Mexico-Canada deal gets worse as Democrats drive it left.. Robert Lighthizer has bent over backward to win labor support for the U.S. trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, but House Democrats are still ordering the U.S. Trade Rep to perform more somersaults.

title: Iraq, Other Countries Support Extra OPEC Cuts
summary: Oil minister said Iraq and other countries would support more cuts by 400,000 barrels to 1.6 million barrels a day. VIENNA-Iraq and some other oil-exporting nations will support deeper production cuts from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies as the cartel attempts to shore up sagging oil prices.

title: Why Bloomberg's Candidacy Is Terminal
summary: His past accomplishments in business and politics are liabilities among today's Democrats.. Michael Bloomberg launched his presidential bid last week at an event in Virginia, where the billionaire former mayor of New York immediately reminded us why no one has ever accused him of being a natural politician. "I think that there is a greater risk of having Donald Trump re-elected than there was before," he said. "And in the end, I looked in the mirror and said I just cannot let this happen." But other than the person staring back at him in the mirror, it's unclear who exactly is beating the drums for a Bloomberg candidacy.

title: Artificial Intelligence and the Adversary
summary: What will Beijing do with the data it stole about American military service members and others?. The potential benefits of artificial intelligence are proclaimed loudly, for all to hear. The dangers, however, are discussed quietly among national-security experts. The time has come to bring the general population into the discussion.

title: Warren Hates Market Concentration-or Does She?
summary: She rails against big banks and tech companies, but Medicare for All would be far more dominant.. Sen. Elizabeth Warren has a contradiction at the center of her political program. On the one hand, she campaigns as a relentless opponent of monopoly and a proponent of vigorous antitrust enforcement. She wants to break up big tech, restrain big banks and try to reduce market concentration throughout the economy. On the other hand, she wants to erect an unshakable monopoly in one of the largest sectors of the economy: health care. Ms. Warren plans to ultimately make private medical insurance illegal and favors a government monopoly to replace their competition.

title: Notable & Quotable: Kamala Harris, Then and Now
summary: 'The 2018 election convinced us that Harris seems to be exactly what Democratic voters are telling the party and its politicians they want.'. From "Why Kamala Harris is the new Democratic Frontrunner" by Chris Cillizza and Harry Enten, CNN.com, Nov. 12, 2018. Ms. Harris announced Tuesday that she was suspending her campaign:
